section_1_key_concepts.overview: Elizabeth I faced massive challenges when she became Queen in 1558: Religion, Marriage, Foreign threats (Spain/France/Scotland), and Legitimacy.
learning_objectives: Evaluate the threat of Mary Queen of Scots

section_2_detailed_explanations.heading: Problems in 1558
section_2_detailed_explanations.content: 1) Religion: Country divided between Catholic/Protestant. 2) Legitimacy: Catholics didn't recognise Henry VIII's marriage to Anne Boleyn. 3) Gender: Many thought a woman couldn't rule. 4) Money: Crown was in debt. 5) France/Scotland: Auld Alliance threat.

section_2_detailed_explanations.heading: The Religious Settlement (1559)
section_2_detailed_explanations.content: Act of Supremacy (Liz = Governor, not Head). Act of Uniformity (New Prayer Book, services in English, some Catholic decorations kept). Goal: A 'Middle Way' to avoid civil war. Result: Generally worked, but angered extremes (Puritans and hardline Catholics).

section_3_worked_examples.question: Explain two consequences of the Religious Settlement (8 marks)
step_by_step: Consequence 1: Relative peace/Stability. It satisfied the majority of moderate people.
Consequence 2: Opposition from extremists. The Papal Bull (1570) excommunicated her, and Puritans began challenging her authority in Parliament.

foundation.question: What year was the Religious Settlement?
foundation.explanation: One year after she became Queen

higher.question: Write an account of the plot against Elizabeth involving Mary Queen of Scots (8 marks)
higher.correct_answer: Focus on Babington Plot / Throckmorton Plot
higher.explanation: Chronological account showing cause and consequence

exam_tips: Know the dates of the plots
common_mistakes: Confusing Mary I (Bloody Mary) with Mary Queen of Scots

resources.title: Elizabethan Portrait Analysis
resources.description: How she used image for power

revision_checklist: I know why MQS was a threat
